text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, so the thing that was the nuance when, uh, the nurse called you the other day? Patient: Uh huh? Doctor: Is what we have found is that people who are on the Xtandi or enzalutamide may have a better likelihood of responding to these medicines. Patient: Oh. I see. Doctor: So, where you don’t qualify for this study is you’re not on Xtandi now. Patient: Right. Doctor: So, for us to think about this trial as an option for you, we would have to restart the Xtandi – Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Check your PSA in a couple weeks and knowing that your ARV seven positive, it’s very likely that the PSA will still be higher. (Pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s different. It’s new. There is buzz out there, but the bottom line in prostate cancer is we don’t know how well these drugs work, if at all. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: “Hello, I’m Mr. P___ I'm on two of Xtandi”. Patient: Yes. Doctor: PSA is starting to do this, uh-oh, we're kind of worried. So, sometimes the cancer gets smart. And now we say look, maybe there's a way to kind of flap that, see if we can get it to work again, because it did work for a while, which was good. So this pill going right along, we want to add a second pill. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: This study is to add a second pill, different pathway, to say hey, I'm gonna see if I add the second guy whether both together will make your PSA drop. But of course, to make things complicated, the second pill, they want to do stuff too. So they're going to have two groups. So if you're in the first group, you keep going on your Xtandi, and you get the second pill at a particular dose, no problem. Then W____ is on the same study, he's on Xtandi two pills a day. And I give him also the second pill at the same dose. Nobody's placebo-ing, you're now on two potentially active medicines, okay. But to make the study even more interesting, what they're doing is, if you are doing okay, on those two doses, they're going to give you an extra, you know, like 40 milligrams every month to see if they can increase that dose to get better mileage on this activity. But W____ is going to also get a matching pill. But his is not an active 40 milligrams, he just gets the sugar version of the 40 milligrams. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But everybody's on the second pill at the right dose, and the Xtandi. ‘ Patient: Okay, I think I understand that. Okay. Doctor: Yes. And if you try to look on the internet, it's not the way it is, they just literally opened this up. So when M____, who was one that was calling you, she just wanted to know if you are even interested. Because if so we would have to get a spot. And then when you come in, you see a W____ equivalent, but just somebody who knows that study better. Kind of like a M____ and a W____hybrid. And you would be seen across the hall in our other area, but you still have me you can't get rid of me. And then we just decide if this is the right thing or not. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The alternative would be you know, let's say you're not eligible or you're not interested, we would try a different study to see; we would get off that Xtandi and try something else. I just said, “Well you are already on the 80 maybe we can get this guy come back and do more.” So that's an option, but there are still more options. So I don't want you to worry if that one is not going to work or is not appealing. We got more options. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Yeah. You have. Doctor: Because we did it before the testosterone, during the testosterone, during the enzalutamide, and we try to look at how those treatments affect it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I’ll, I’ll find out. Patient: Alright. Doctor: So- Family Member: I wanted, I want your input, uh but we couldn’t just give him that - because he is all at that level of three injections of testosterone, he’s a perfect candidate just for that immune thing just to see? (Beeping) Doctor: Well, the immune thing is normally I, I don’t. We’re not allowed to give anything unless it’s in a disease where it’s been approved- Patient: Mm Hmm. Doctor: because the cost is so very high, the hospital won’t let us do anything. Family Member: So you can’t ask-? Doctor: Now you, you know, who have, you’re a person of means, that maybe you could just pay for it, but I haven’t really, I don’t know what the avenue is to do that. (Laughs) Family Member: Well-

text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So if you have one of those gasping things, if it’s your old gasping problem or is it the new drug? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So then we’re going to put you on steroids and stuff like that. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It can attack your colon so then you can have just profuse, non-stop diarrhea and so that we have to stop as well. It can attack your liver so then you get a hepatitis- Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: that’s not uh virus-related but drug related. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: There’s other parts of the body. Any part of your body could get one of these “-itises” —pneumonitis, hepatitis, colitis. So we’re tuned to listen to you and let you, teach you how to tell us right away if there is something going on and then we have to judge fast where we think worried/not worried. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: That’s experimental; we don’t know what the real benefit to someone like you is. We can’t tell you we’re going to make you live longer.

text: Family Member: It’s the placebo thing? Doctor: Right. So, it’s placebo in the sense that the new drug is not guaranteed but it’s not placebo in the sense everybody gets chemo. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So, if there’s, you know, you’re guy one and you’re guy two you both get chemo no matter what. You might get drug and you might not. Patient: I got you, okay. Doctor: One of them you know. The other one you don’t. So, some it’s like oh, I’m just gonna get stuff infused in but we all kind of go gee, I wonder and it becomes a topic every time. The nurses try to guess. Everybody tries to guess. No one knows the answer except the people who actually hold the key. And then the other one is you know whether you get it or not because they just tell you okay, you’re just getting the chemo. But, the difference is you know everybody gets the chemo. That’s your standard drug. Nobody gets gipped out of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, a good question. It’s something that I have to always make sure people understand. At this stage in the game you should never be on a placebo only trial. Like it can never be either drug X or you’re crap out of luck. No, that’s never gonna happen. Okay? Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And if anybody ever offers you that, that’s bad news. That’s just ethically wrong. So, we have a lot of watchdogs, safeguards, everybody’s looking to make sure that we don’t do something like that. Patient: Okay, Alright. Doctor: Yeah, keep going.

text: Patient: Do you know that for sure? Doctor: Were married to people in England, had children in England. So, I’m English, right? And, then, my moth --- my grandmother’s German. My grandfather is English. So I’m going to do my Ancestry.com just to confirm, um, you know, those are my things. Family Member: I betcha you’re German, like us, yeah. Doctor: No English. I don’t even know how it’s possible because Doctor: It came back, like, I was German. My mother is Italian. That was there. The German was there, but it didn’t even mention English. And then, there was a little note, saying, “A low probability, four percent, English.” Like, no, that’s impossible because, English, English, English, English. Doctor: I see all of this, and I’m like, hmmm, I wonder if one of my great grandfathers is not English. (Laughs) Patient: He might have been a Norman. Doctor: He might have been! Patient: Which would be worse than anything. Doctor: Maybe they were, yeah. I don’t know. No, I think, that’s French, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: No, I don’t have any French. Doctor: I had some Spanish-Portuguese, maybe

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
